entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
06/17 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-eleventh edition:

Laura:
  • MetroGit - Paris Metro stations visualised as a git graph
  • First Pull Request - A nifty tool to see the first pull request you ever sent on GitHub.
  • Cutting Corners or Why Rails May Kill Ruby - A very interesting and to-the-point article about “monkey-patching all the things” and why it might be terrible for our ecosystem, by Piotr Solnica
Floor:
  • Fonts that actually work together - Skillcrush helps the non-design-savvy with free font pairings that WORK.
  • apipie - Apipie is an interesting tool/gem for documenting your Rails API.
  • rice steamer - don’t think on it, simply register for this new event format at sektor5. Zero regrets guaranteed.
Gerald:
  • FizzBuzz @ Rosetta Code - the “classic” exercise in hundred of (inspiring) versions
  • FizzBuzz In Too Much Detail - write-up about the Fizz Buzz exercise in Ruby – from simple “classic” style to fully “modern” functional-style with clear separation of side effects (i/o functions)
  • Ruby Books Page @ Planet Ruby - summer beach reading recommendations
  • The Architecture of Open Source Applications - inspiring (free) book series about studying real world (patterns) code (applications) incl. Volume I, Volume II, Performance Edition and the upcoming 500-Lines-or-Less Edition

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
06/10 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-tenth edition:

Laura:
  • caniuse - a caniuse.com command line tool
  • Getting Started with Ruby Processing - the simplicity of Ruby coupled with the awesomeness of Processing
  • Hologram - A markdown-based documentation system for style guides
Aaron:
  • Icomoon, generate project icon fonts - A service I have been using for a long time. Great to organize icon fonts for your web app
  • Talk: Yak Shaving is Best Shaving - A great talk from Baruco 2013 (I said I would be adding these ;) by tenderlove. The a yak shaving into the internals of Ruby. Yaks all the way down.
Floor:
  • Rubyslava Conf'15 - Rubyslava is celebrating their 50th meetup with a free conference <3 Talking about events, Herr Bauer added some great upcoming ones on Awesome Events
  • We all love Cheal - Especially when he talks robots and IoT on the Ruby Rogues podcast
  • status:success - Filter your Pull Requests by their Status
Dave:
  • Apache Lucene is an amazing Java library for doing indexing and searching of your data. It’s the core of Apache Solr and v5.2.0 was just released.
  • Apache Solr - scalable blazing fast search platform
  • ElasticSearch - a well-known commercial product based on the core Lucene technology
  • LogStash - JRuby based analytics tool
  • Kibana - a superb browser based analytics and search dashboard
  • RSolr - a low-level gem for talking to Solr
  • Sunspot - a nifty gem & DSL for talking to Solr directly

All of these are using Inverted Indexes - a really nice explanation.

Markus:
  • Daniel Steinberg - The Ugly American Learns Swift (dotSwift 2015) - On the importance of communities and being open to new and different ways of doing things, especially when learning a new language.
  • Distributed Systems Are a UX Problem - Why “solving” distributed systems might not just be an entirely technical process.
  • “Badass - Making Users Awesome” by Kathy Sierra - It doesn’t just make your users more awesome.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
06/03 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-ninth edition:

Laura:
  • hirb - view framework for console/irb
  • solved by flexbox - vertically aligning with css.. a dream come true.
  • lolcat - an oldie but goldie: rainbows and unicorns!
Aaron:
  • Unpacking Ampersand + To_proc - Article about writing tighter Ruby code. Helpful if you aren’t using the (&:message) syntax or have never heard of it.
  • Rubyconf Portugal 14-15 September - I went last year (their first year) and it was fantastic. The lineup looks great and Braga and the venue are very nice. Maybe I’ll see you there!
Floor:
  • Github Engineering Blog - Github recently released their all-new Engineering blog.
  • Tropical Ruby - Tropical Ruby released talk recordings from their March' conference. Worth checking out!

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
05/27 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-eighth edition:

Laura:
  • Emoji Minesweeper - Because this is the internet and you get what you ask for.
  • Daily things you can do to help you with writing code - Some pretty neat advice by Zach Holman.
Aaron:
  • Spina CMS - The new Rails powered CMS on the block.
  • Oga - A (mostly) Ruby Nokogiri replacement. It aims to be cross Ruby implementation and thread safe. Looks interesting.
Floor:
  • Ruby Heroes - Listen to my favorite podcast people from The Changelog talking with 2015’s Ruby Heroes.
  • Ariel Waldman is so awesome - Github talked to space kid Ariel Waldman about her experiences at NASA and her upcoming CodeConf talk.
  • Atom swag - There’s an Atom shirt in the Octoshop, to celebrate Atom’s 1 year anniversary. Also, Github will release a Pridetocat shirt to celebrate Pride Week.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
05/20 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-seventh edition:

Laura:
  • Awesome Print - Pretty print your Ruby objects with style
  • The Secret Life of your Database, part 1: Migrations - a neat little article that take a look at database migrations. Bonus: the rake db:migrate:status command, which I had never used before <3
  • everyenv - rbenv, but for ANYTHING
Aaron:
  • Why Everyone Hates Go - An interesting take on why golang has so many haters. Angular could also fall into this reasoning.
  • Speakers Chosen For Full Stack Fest - This conference looks like a must see. Amazing lineup.
  • Talks from Baruco 2013 - Since we’re talking about Baruco (Full Stack Fest), here are the talks from 2013. It was, and still probably is, the best conference I have ever been to. It’s super hard to pick a best, I think I’ll pick them individually in the next editions of our picks!
Floor:
  • ReadRemaining.js - Tell your readers how long they’ll need to get through all of your gibberish, with this clever jQuery plugin.
  • ROSSConf Berlin - Because who needs sleep, when there’s conferences to organize?
Dave:

For the love of crypto! Elliptic Curves are the new hotness, especially given shock revelations of recent years regarding protocol flaws, government capability and general internet-enabled data collection. Here’s some links to get your teeth into, but not biting off more than you can chew!

Why should you care? Well, ECC-based Ed25519 ssh keys are shorter, almost memorisable, noticeably faster for session setup times, and throughput is improved! What’s not to like? Similar advances are available in TLS and PGP. Be warned, not all OS, apps and browsers support these yet.

  • The Death of BitCoin - a well supported but controversial view of BitCoin’s future, touching on ECC.
  • A gentle introduction to ECC - if you ignore most of the math this is indeed a gentle introduction.
  • Another gentle introduction to ECC - this is slightly less gentle but may be easier to digest as a video!
  • Post-quantum Crypto - I just bookmarked this one for “later reading” when my brain has expanded but anything by D.J.Bernstein and T.Lange is always worth the time spent understanding.
  • Securing SSH - a practical application of all the hard science you just skimmed ;-)

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
05/13 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-sixth edition:

Laura:
  • Dash - Offline API documentation sets
  • npwd - Command-line password management for your various accounts
  • Night of Support - Some shameless promotion! Night of Support is coming this Friday to a sektor5 near you.
Aaron:
  • Faster Search with PostgreSQL - A really straight forward way to increase search performance using PostgreSQL’s full text search and the JSON data type
  • Why Rails 5 / Turbolinks 3.0 / Action Cable matter, and why @dhh was right all along - Controversial article about Rails 5’s new set of features. Also a good intro to Rails 5’s new features.
Floor:
  • RubyThursday - Build a portfolio in a fun and engaging way. What if you had access to a set of fresh Ruby on Rails projects and tutorials that helped you consistently code on a regular basis?
  • Atom for Rails - Setting up Atom for Rails Development
  • Upset baby in pure CSS - thihihi.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
05/06 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-fifth edition:

Laura:
  • Gitignore - A collection of useful gitignore templates
  • What’s your least favourite thing about Ruby? - because sometimes, just sometimes, we have to go there
Floor:
  • FizzBuzz Pro - Solving the FizzBuzz test without a single If statement
  • Not just unicode - How to store emoji in a Rails app with a MySQL database
  • Rails on Codecademy - Codecademy added a course on Ruby on Rails 4. By the end of the course, you’ll be able to use Ruby on Rails to create your own apps.
Gerald:
  • Ruby Performance Optimization: Why Ruby Is Slow, and How to Fix It - New (Beta) Book in the Pragmatic Programmers Ruby Series
  • Awesome Markdown - Yet another awesome collection on GitHub about all things Markup and Markdown
  • Linuxwochen Wien @ FH Technikum, May/7-9 - New Event in Vienna; Free; Everyone Welcome
  • Introducing datapak - Work with Tabular Data Packages using Ruby and ActiveRecord - Article about Working w/ Open Data and SQL(ite) in Ruby

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
04/29 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-fourth edition:

Laura:
  • thef*ck - magnificent app which corrects your previous console command
  • railsdiff - View diff of app configuration for different Rails versions
  • Contributing to Open Source projects - Alex Williams wrote a short recap of last weekend’s ROSSConf on his blog
Floor:
  • Picture proof - Can’t help but falling in love with the gorgeous pictures Manuel Gruber took at ROSS Conf
  • ROSS Conf decks - We collected the slides from ROSS Conf for you to relive the good times

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
04/22 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-third edition:

Laura:
  • Estimating time for web projects more accurately - in spite of it being really old, this article is a pretty good overview of how to somewhat accurately estimate web projects.
  • 12 resolutions for programmers - Challenge yourself with a new, month-sized, resolution every month.
  • Existing HTML rel values - Entertaining to see how many strange rel values exist in HTML (hashtag: crush)
Floor:
  • Sublime 3.0 - This is a pick for Laura; setting up Sublime Text 3 for Ruby Development.
  • Arrrrcamp CFP is open - Because speaking at ArrrrCamp is arrrrsome!
  • awesome events - Gerald collects awesome (Ruby related) events in his awesome events repo.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
04/15 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-second edition:

Laura:
  • 10 years of Git - Git turns ten years old this month!
  • Potter API - Just what it sounds like: A Harry Potter API.
  • Markdown Processing in Ruby - A look at four different Ruby implementations of Markdown
Floor:
  • Awesome Ruby - A collection of awesome Ruby libraries, tools, frameworks and software, sorted alphabetically.
  • Ruby Rogues #202 - The Struggles New Ruby Users Have with Jake Day Williams
Gerald:
  • New Book: Ruby Cookbook, 2nd Edition - A massive collection of Ruby recipes (1000+ pages) e.g. cook yourself an API service w/ Sinatra, and much more. Free sample chapter on “What’s News in Ruby 2.1”.
  • Jekyll on Rails - add Jekyll - a static site generator - to your Rails app; step by step instructions incl. how-to-use Rails-like asset pipeline in Jekyll
  • Free Event: Ruby Meetup in Linz, Upper Austria - why not visit Linz and join this year’s first Ruby Meetup in Upper Austria on May 20th at the AXIS Coworking Loft?

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
04/08 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-first edition:

Laura:
  • Editing a pen in Sublime - Just what it says
  • Blurst - A genetic algorithm experiment
Aaron:
  • Rubytype - Type contracts for your Ruby methods.
  • Running Rails jobs in background threads - Some gotchas on how to run code in background threads in your Rails app.
  • [Blocks are Procs in disguise][8] - Why blocks make Ruby methods 439% slower.
Floor:
  • Rails Girls Summer of Code hit their funding goal - NOW LET’S FUND AN ELEVENTH TEAM CAUSE WHY THE HECK NOT?!
  • Why SCRUM Backlogs lead to bad Product Decisions - it’s an oldie, yet still one for the must-read list, by the wonderful @__tosh
  • Hamburger Menu Icons - and how to animate them in/with CSS-Only
Markus:
  • “Allow foreign tables to participate in inheritance” - PostgreSQL 9.5 will get native sharding support
  • Ruby Tricks of Questionable Usefulness - Jamis Buck presents a few fascinating features showing just how malleable Ruby is
  • 20,000 Leagues Under ActiveRecord - The first of four posts by Pat Shaughnessy exploring how an ActiveRecord expression is processed all the way down to PostgreSQL
Phillipp:
  • “Crystal language” - Ruby inspired syntax, but compiled. Faster than go in some benchmarks, btw! Compiler started in Ruby, compiles itself by now.
Gerald:
  • Ruby Gem of the Week Series @ Planet Ruby - Gems so far include factbook, hoe, gli, kramdown, feedparser, and many more
  • New Book: The Ruby Way, 3rd Edition - Free Sample Chapter: Working with Strings in Ruby
  • Join the Discussion at Jekyll Talk - Jekyll - a static site generator in Ruby - has now a discourse-powered discussion forum

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
04/01 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundredth (!!!) edition:

Laura:
  • Space Apps Challenge - The Space Apps Challenges are online in preparation for the worldwide NASA Hackathon next week. \o/
  • Debugging Memory Leaks in Ruby - Sam Saffron walks us through the current tooling to hunt down memory leaks
  • Nth-Test - The ultimate nth-child visual tester
Aaron:
  • Hack This Site - “a free, safe and legal training ground for hackers to test and expand their hacking skills.” There are hacking contests and other pretty neat stuff.
  • 15 Top Ruby/Rails Events Around The Globe - A nice list of Ruby and Rails events/conferences around the world with descriptions.
  • My Moleskine GTD System - I’ve been trying to do more writing lately… you know… with a pen and paper. I almost forgot how to do it. This article shows an interesting way to move your GTD system from Omni Focus or Wunderlist to a handy moleskine.
Floor:
  • one cfp to rule them all - cfp for EuRuKo, eurucamp and jRubyConf are now open.
  • Google Maps PAC-MAN - YES.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
03/25 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the ninety-ninth edition:

Laura:
  • eurucamp CFP - The eurucamp Call for Proposals is now open!
  • Try SQL - There’s a new SQL course in town (aka on CodeSchool)
Aaron:
  • Tired of conditionals? State pattern could help - If you missed Markus Prinz’s talk about state machines, or you want to know more, here’s a great article for you.
  • Heroku upgrade to Cedar-14 - Cedar-10 reaches its end of life on November 4th 2015. Upgrade ASAP so you don’t get screwed at the last minute.
Floor:
  • the changelog - A beginner’s guide to creating a README
  • ROSS Conf Vienna - who doesn’t want to pair with Michal Papis, Katrina Owen or Arne Brasseur?
  • Open Source Camp - Open Source Camp is an initiative with selected talents, experts, early stage start-ups and project teams who meet for an intensive two-day workshop and join forces as a community. Plus: you could end up getting funding via the netidee call.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
03/18 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the ninety-eighth edition:

Laura:
  • A Talk About Nothing - Lena Reinhard’s insightful “Talk About Nothing” from this year’s concat()
  • CSS Sans - Taking CSS to a whole new level – here’s to you the Css Typeface.
  • Computer Science for Babies - Because it’s never too early to understand binary
Aaron:
  • RubyConf Kenya - May 8th-9th
Floor:
  • ROSS Conf Vienna - … is a one day mini-conference bringing Open Source Software maintainers and developers together in one room. Its first edition includes the exercism project from Katrina Owen and RVM from Michal Papis.
  • RubyRogues - on expanding the Ruby Community Values to Other Languages with Scott Feinberg and Mark Bates
  • Mind the Gender Parity Gap - The Changeloggers talk to Sarah Mei about her elaborate blog on Gender Parity

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
03/11 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the ninety-seventh edition:

Laura:
  • Making attendees feel safe at conferences - A great post by the concat() team about making attendees feel safe and welcome at their conference
  • 7 Must Have Development Gems - Some gems that make debugging and development a little easier for you
  • Implementing A visual CSS Testing Framework - I love the idea of testing CSS like this for large codebases
Aaron:
  • Includes vs Joins in Rails: When and where? | - A post from Tom Dallimore about the difference between ActiveRecord joins and includes methods. The differences surprised me.
  • Foodhack Vienna - I am organizing a hackathon on March 28th and 29th in Vienna to build software to help reduce food waste. We currently throw away 20% of our food… yikes.
  • The Case for Case - If you are using a lot of if and elsif’s in your code, Daniel Clark shows you some of the practical and more obscure ways to start implementing case statements instead.
Floor:
  • RGSoC - Find out how your company can support Rails Girls Summer of Code!
  • Github - ehhh - Google Summer of Code - GitHub has been selected to participate as a mentoring organization for Google Summer of Code. If you want to work with a GitHubber on an open source project, check out our list of project ideas (Atom!).
  • Real Pirates Ship - The new Octocat shirt is grrreat! (scroll down to the map #SeaPlusplus).

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
03/04 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the ninety-sixth edition:

Laura:
  • Awesomeplete - Simple autocomplete widget with zero dependencies
  • Visualize your git - because, well, git. <3
  • Git(Hub) Cheatsheet - see above.
Aaron:
  • The Volt Framework - Volt is a newer Ruby web framework which has a goal of sharing Ruby on the frontend and backend. I am pretty excited about it
  • Isomorphic App Development with Ruby and Volt by Ryan Stout - A great talk about Volt by its creator.
  • Why Timehop Chose Go to Replace Our Rails App - I have been writing some Go code lately and this is an interesting article about one team’s choice to switch when trying to scale their rails app.
Floor:
  • HTML5 number inputs - Because I hate it when an app doesn’t recognize both a comma AND a period as decimal marks
  • Motion Blur experiment - Because I like this

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
02/25 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the ninety-fifth edition:

Laura:
  • Ruby Habits - There’s a new Ruby meetup/study group in town!
  • Traveling Ruby - Self-contained, “portable” Ruby binaries
  • Life Beyond Rails - A brief look at alternate web frameworks for Ruby
Aaron:
  • Euroku in Salzburg! - Euroko was cancelled last year because of the political unrest in Kiev and the panel has picked Salzburg to be the next venue October 17-18th. See you there!!!
  • Learn to read the source Luke - codinghorror tells us that documentation is crap and that the source code is the source of all truth. Learn to read it.
Floor:
  • Mini Conf - Rubyslava is celebrating its 4 years anniversary with a Mini Conference / Lightning talk edition
  • huewheel - a HUE color wheel for HTML5 browsers, make sure to try the demo
  • RVM1 maintainers - Papis is looking for YOU

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
02/18 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the ninety-fourth edition:

Laura:
  • MailCatcher - Test your emails like WHOA
  • Becoming a Jekyll God - If you weren’t at our last meetup, you won’t get it ;)
  • Ruby Heroes - Get nominatin'!
Aaron:
  • 95% of performance is about clean representative models - Really great talk about how writing “clean code” and OOP best practice can boost your performance at the compiler level. The best talk I have seen in a long time. Warning: Java inside.
  • Why the Hell Does Your API Still Use HTTP Basic Auth? - Your API may be exposing your customers' password in clear text. Interesting insights into security and UX tradeoffs.
  • Finding Your Way Around a New Rails Project - If you are dumped into a legacy Rails project, here are some tips to finding out WTF is going on.
Floor:
  • Wi-Fi password - Cool little Bash script to quickly fetch your Wi-Fi password from OS X’s keychain.
  • Rikki - Katrina Owen has recently added a nitpicking robot to Exercism — an app that lets you practice your coding and get crowd-sourced mentorship - called Rikki.
  • JSConf Budapest - a JSConf family member 2-day non-profit for-the-community by-the-community conference about JavaScript JUST AROUND THE CORNER! Now if you could all use my couponcode LEKKERKAASJSCONFBP you get a €50 discount and I get to send someone to Budapest who could otherwise not afford it <3

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
02/11 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the ninety-third edition:

Laura:
  • RegexOne - Learn Regular Expressions with simple, interactive examples
  • DidIt - For all if you Productivity nerds.. There’s an IDoneThis command line client
Aaron:
  • Rake file tasks - A good intro to rake file tasks starting from the bare minimum
  • First and Rest in Ruby - A really neat way to implement first and rest, common functions in functional languages, in Ruby.
  • Ansible for Rubyists - This is a very basic intro to Ansible, aimed at people who are used to capistrano/mina.
Floor:
  • Dream - Dream is a music video done in Ruby with gamebox. And it’s interesting.
  • Jazz Fingers - Pry-based enhancements for the default Rails 3 and 4 consoles. Rrrr.
  • Material - This Bootstrap theme is an easy way to use the new Material Design guidelines by Google in your Bootstrap 3 based application.
  • CSS Animation - Recreating Twitter’s brand new ‘fave’ animation.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
02/04 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the ninety-second edition:

Laura:
  • GreatHaikuBot - basically tech haikus.. because why not.
  • Pairing with Junior Developers - A few tips that might come in handy if you’re considering pairing.
  • RGSoC: Call for Projects - The Rails Girls Summer of Code is accepting projects for its 2015 programme. DO EET!
Floor:
  • Signal - The CFP for Signal, Twilio’s technical conference about how developers are changing communications, is open.
  • gauguin - Nifty tool for retrieving the main colors from an image.
  • roarrr - Because sexy: compositing and blending in CSS.
